Award.AwardTitle: The Long-Term Socioeconomic Dynamics of Resettlement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Economic growth depends of the development of infrastructures that allow for enterprise to thrive and innovate. Infrastructural development often significantly impacts the communities in which it takes place, and transportation and energy initiatives, for example, can require that these communities be displaced and resettled. Public confidence in these efforts depends on the mitigation of uneven development outcomes to these displaced communities. Scientists know much about the short-term dynamics of displacement and resettlement. This research would give scientists a rare opportunity to understand those dynamics over the long-term. In addition, the project would strengthen collaboration among international communities of scientists, train a graduate student in methods of scientifically-grounded and empirical data collection, and contribute data that would be of benefit to public policy experts concerned with development and resettlement.

Dr. Dolores Koenig of the American University will lead a team of researchers investigating the long-term dynamics of forced displacement and resettlement resulting from large infrastructural development projects. The research would revisit a region for which there is substantial baseline data and analyses: the Manantali dam in Mali, which displaced large numbers of Senegal River Basin residents in the late 1980s. The projects asks whether the long-term impacts of forced displacement and resettlement vary depending on the access that resettled individuals and their descendants have to economic and social resources. In collaboration with researchers from the Institut des Sciences Humains in Bamako, the research team will track household samples from two studies of migrants conducted in the 1980s, and another larger sample from a study conducted in 1993-94. Date will be gathered at four different sites with varied access to resources, to test whether livelihood and other decision-making strategies differ significantly. Data on food security, socioeconomic status, social organization and kinship, health care and education access, consumption patterns, and a range of other decision-making practices will be collected through interviews and other ethnographic data collection techniques. The project will advance anthropological and other scientific understandings about economic livelihoods and their sustainability, and the social structures that sustain livelihoods and access to resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study of the long-term socioeconomic dynamics of resettlement looked at livelihoods and standards of living among the people of the Bafing valley and their descendants. Some 850-10,000 people who lived in the reservoir area of the Manantali dam in western Mali were displaced by the rising water in the new reservoir. A resettlement project funded by the US government moved them into new villages and hamlets in the mid-1980s, mostly downstream from the dam.

Research was carried out by a team of Dolores Koenig, Tieman Diarra, Moussa Sow, N’gna Traore, Kama Dembele, and Rokia Traore. All except Koenig (the PI) were recruited through Mali’s Institut des Sciences Humaines. Together the team spent approximately 3-4 months in Manantali and other area sites, during 4 different field visits; the team also presented results to community members in January 2019. Koenig spent additional time in Mali, working with the research team on project design, preparation of data for qualitative and quantitative analysis, data entry, and data analysis.

The forced relocation and subsequent resettlement remain defining life events for the older people in the area. Many of them attribute the negative features of their contemporary lives to their loss of old lands and the resettlement. At the same time, it is clear that the resettlement was not the only major event that touched their lives. In the late 1980s, just after the resettlement, they experienced structural adjustment, the international policy meant to make greater use of market forces and to remove government constraints on private-sector economic activity. On the one hand, resettlers were disadvantaged because the rural development organization that had provided credit, fertilizers, and other inputs was disbanded since it was not economically sustainable. On the other hand, resettlers benefitted because they were able to take advantage of the growth of private commerce and transport. The second major change that affected them occurred in the 1990s, when a newly democratized Mali undertook a process of political decentralization that replaced appointed local administrators with elected municipal governments. The experiences they had working with project administrators during the resettlement prepared them to embrace the new elected governments. Local governments worked with their constituencies to bring new schools and health services to the region, and many residents participate in one form or another in local government and political action. People also regularly address elected representatives to assist in dealing with domestic problems, such as forced marriage or wife beating, as well as inter-village conflicts over farmland and animal grazing areas.

In this context, the resettlers and their descendants have created lives and follow livelihoods that were unimaginable to them in the early 1980s. Because of significant population growth, as well as difficulties in investing in soil conservation, agriculture is rarely sufficiently productive to feed their families for the entire year, which was generally possible before the resettlement. However, people have undertaken a variety of other income-earning activities, including commerce, entrepreneurship, long and short-term salaried jobs, and long and short-term wage labor migration. In this way they have earned incomes sufficient not only to buy food, but also to send children to school and pay for health care and to purchase new consumer goods, such as motorcycles, cell phones, and solar panels. Instead of seeing themselves as an isolated population, residents generally now consider themselves to be disadvantaged members of a national class system that generally benefits the urban educated. Even though they have more than they had before resettlement, they now consider themselves “poor.” This study has shown the complexity of long-term change after resettlement, where people benefit in some ways, but are disadvantaged in others. It also shows how the greater integration into national hierarchies common after forced resettlement offers new perspectives and possibilities, with both advantages and disadvantages.

These results should also provide data to allow better resettlement planning. It shows that reconstruction of livelihoods, the goal of development policies, is quite complicated. People want to reconstruct the positive aspects of their previous livelihoods, but at the same time, they also want to benefit from the new opportunities that come from infrastructure development. This means that they usually pursue new livelihoods that combine aspects of old and new. Resettlement policies should recognize more directly the impossibility of continuing old livelihoods after resettlement; programs should provide more training to the resettled so they can take full advantage of new opportunities. In addition, this research accentuates the importance of preserving social units, such as villages and districts, after resettlement. This allows people to take advantage of new institutions, such as elected governments.
